clusters.name: Increase Housing Supply Through Zoning Reform
clusters.summary: These residents are advocating for dramatically increasing housing supply across NYC through various strategies including zoning deregulation, dense development, accessory dwelling units, and better transit connections to enable housing in underutilized areas.
clusters.action: City officials should reform zoning regulations to allow higher density development, prioritize transit infrastructure investments (especially to Staten Island), and streamline permitting processes to enable both market-rate and affordable housing construction at scale.

synthesized_actions.title: Citywide ADU Streamlining Program
synthesized_actions.proposal: Establish a streamlined ADU approval process across all five boroughs by eliminating parking requirements, reducing setback restrictions by 50%, and creating a 60-day fast-track permitting process for pre-approved ADU designs. Launch pilot program in 5 Community Districts (one per borough) by July 2025, with goal of approving 1,000 new ADUs within first year. Include zoning text amendments to allow ADUs as-of-right in all R4-R10 districts.
supporting_demands: Allow and streamline accessory dwelling units (ADUs) across all boroughs
Reduce restrictive zoning regulations to enable more housing development

synthesized_actions.title: Large-Scale Infill Housing Initiative
synthesized_actions.proposal: Create mandatory inclusionary housing program requiring 25% affordable units in all new developments of 50+ units, while rezoning underutilized corridors within 0.5 miles of subway stations to allow minimum 6-story mixed-use development. Target production of 100,000 new units over 5 years through building conversions and infill development. Establish $2 billion Housing Development Fund to build city-owned housing complexes of 5+ stories on city-controlled land, starting with 2,000 units on Governor's Island by 2027.

synthesized_actions.title: Staten Island Transit-Oriented Development
synthesized_actions.proposal: Launch 3-year pilot program implementing Tokyo-style zoning (allowing mixed residential/commercial by-right with height limits based on street width) in 2-square-mile area around St. George Terminal. Simultaneously initiate environmental review for subway tunnel connection to Staten Island with federal partnership, targeting construction start by 2028. Expand SIR service with 15-minute peak frequency and new stations to support 10,000 new transit-oriented housing units by 2030.

Implement Tokyo-style zoning as pilot program on Staten Island
Expand passenger rail network citywide

clusters.name: Sidewalk Width Standards
clusters.summary: Residents are advocating for establishing mandatory minimum sidewalk widths and creating a funding program to upgrade narrow sidewalks citywide.
clusters.action: Implement zoning regulations requiring 8-foot minimum sidewalk widths for new development and establish a dedicated funding program to systematically widen existing substandard sidewalks throughout the city.

demands.description: Establish minimum sidewalk width standards of 8 feet in zoning regulations

synthesized_actions.title: Sidewalk Standards and Improvement Program
synthesized_actions.proposal: Amend the city zoning code to establish a minimum sidewalk width of 8 feet for all new developments and major renovations, effective January 1, 2025. Simultaneously launch a 5-year sidewalk improvement program with $2 million annual funding to widen existing substandard sidewalks (under 8 feet) to meet the new standard. Prioritize improvements near schools, transit stops, and high-pedestrian areas. Complete environmental review and begin construction on first 10 blocks by July 2025.
supporting_demands: Establish minimum sidewalk width standards of 8 feet in zoning regulations

nodes.summary: Set minimum sidewalk width of 8 feet tied to zoning; fund widening program for substandard sidewalks.

clusters.action: Systematically redesign streets to widen sidewalks at the expense of vehicle lanes, implement car-free zones around schools, and invest in pedestrian infrastructure including improved crosswalks, street furniture, and connectivity between neighborhoods.

synthesized_actions.title: Complete Streets Redesign Pilot

clusters.name: Green Flood Resilience Infrastructure
clusters.summary: Residents are advocating for replacing car-dominated spaces with permeable green infrastructure in flood-prone areas to enhance the city's climate resilience.
clusters.action: City officials should prioritize converting parking spaces and roadways into green infrastructure with permeable surfaces in neighborhoods identified as flood-prone, focusing on areas that can serve dual purposes of community green space and stormwater management.

demands.description: Install permeable infrastructure and green space in flood-prone areas to replace car parking/roads for climate resilience

synthesized_actions.title: Flood-Resilient Green Infrastructure Pilot
synthesized_actions.proposal: Launch a 2-year pilot program converting 25% of surface parking spaces and one lane of roadway in the three most flood-prone commercial districts into permeable green infrastructure. Install rain gardens, bioswales, and permeable pavement by December 2025. Allocate $2.5 million from stormwater management funds. Measure flood reduction, air quality improvement, and business impact metrics quarterly. Upon demonstrating 30% flood reduction, expand program to 5 additional districts by 2027.
supporting_demands: Install permeable infrastructure and green space in flood-prone areas to replace car parking/roads for climate resilience

nodes.summary: Increase permeable infrastructure/replace car space with green space in flood-prone areas for resilience.

synthesized_actions.proposal: Launch a comprehensive upgrade program for 25 high-traffic subway stations over 18 months, starting January 2025. Funding through capital improvement bonds with $2M allocated per station. Complete environmental review by March 2025, begin construction by summer 2025.

synthesized_actions.title: Comprehensive Traffic Safety Enhancement
synthesized_actions.proposal: Implement a three-phase traffic safety program: Phase 1 (6 months) - Install automated speed cameras on 25 high-accident corridors and extend parking restrictions to 2-hour limits in commercial districts with dedicated 30-minute delivery zones. Phase 2 (months 7-12) - Launch congestion pricing pilot in downtown core ($5 peak hours, $2 off-peak) with goal of reducing vehicle traffic by 15%. Phase 3 (year 2) - Convert 5 school-adjacent blocks to car-free zones during school hours (7:30-8:30am, 2:30-3:30pm). Revenue from enforcement and pricing funds safety infrastructure improvements. Evaluate crash reduction metrics quarterly.
